bestBHT.bht: In spite of Paul's repudiation of idolatrous tendencies, it didn't take long for such inclinations to surface in the Christian Church and ultimately be established in the Church of Rome. The people were fervently convinced that the gods had appeared and zealous to honor them. The people's fury was barely pacified, revealing the world's vehement passion for idolatry. Idolaters often reject religious beliefs that don't align with their desires. Convincing the people to abstain from offering sacrifices was no easy task, but they eventually succeeded in persuading them to return to their homes.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: In spite of this, and Peter's repudiation of all such honor, how soon idolatrous tendencies began to show themselves in the Christian Church..."
At length to be systematized and enjoined in the Church of Rome!
Albert Barnes: They were so fully satisfied that the gods had appeared.
They were so full of zeal to do them honor.
John Calvin: The fury of the people was scarce appeased - with that vehemency, whereby appeareth how mad and untamed the heat of the world is toward idolatry.
For if they believe the [them] gods, why do they not believe their word, whereby they put from them false honor?
But all idolaters are sick of this disease, that they are oftentimes ready to shake off the yoke unless religion be subject to their will and pleasure.
Archibald T. Robertson: Scarce (μολις). Adverb in same sense as old μογις, from μολος, toil.
Restrained (κατεπαυσαν). Effective first aorist active indicative of καταπαυω, old verb in causative sense to make abstain from.
It had been a harrowing and well-nigh a horrible ordeal, but finally Paul had won. If only nobody else had interposed!
John Gill: And with these sayings, scarce restrained they the people, that they had not done sacrifice unto them.
So resolute were they upon it, that it was with great difficulty that they persuaded them from it.
In four of Beza's manuscripts, and in some other copies, it is added, 'but everyone went to his own house', &c.
